SEARCH
Package sprouts

Class Result<V>

java.lang.Object
sprouts.Result<V>
Type Parameters:
V - The type of the item wrapped by this result.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Maybe<V>
public final class Result<V> extends Object implements Maybe<V>
A Result is very similar to an Optional in that it can either contain an item or not, with the difference being that a result can also contain a list of Problems which describe what went wrong in the process of getting the item wrapped by the result. So usually, if the result is not present, there will most likely be one or more Problems explaining why the value is not present and what went wrong. But the result may also be just empty, exactly like an Optional.
The Result relies on the custom Problem type instead of raw Exception types, because not every runtime issue is or should necessarily be produced by an exception. If you do not want to disturb the control flow of your application by throwing an exception, you can create a Problem as part of a Result and continue processing as usual.
Another very common use case is to use a Result instead of checked exceptions as part of an API that values both compile time enforced error handling and developer experience. A result may catch and wrap an internal system exception to avoid disturbing the control flow of the API consumers while at the same time confronting the API user with the fact that a problem may exist. There, a Result exposes a versatile API for handling all possible (non-fatal) scenarios. This is especially important in cases where the consumer has no control over these errors and cannot handle them in any meaningful way, but instead just wants to opt-into an alternative value through methods like orElse(Object), or orElseGet(Supplier).
Consider the following example as a demonstration for how to use a result at the implementation side of things: 

  public Result<Doc> parse(String doc) {
      return Result.ofTry(Doc.class,()->{
          // An algorithm which may fail!
          // ...or returns a document...
      });
  }
A user of that method may then safely react to an exceptional case instead of experiencing a control flow interruption: 

  var rawText = loadText();
  var parser = new DocParser();
  Doc doc = parser.parse(rawText)
                  .logProblemsAsError()
                  .orElse(Doc.EMPTY);

    Result<V>
    logProblemsAsDebug()
    Irrespective of this Result wrapping a non-null item of type V or not, if the Result has at least one Problem, then an invocation to this method will generate a rich context message and stack trace from its problems and then log them as debug to the Logger.debug(String, Throwable) method, or System.out, if Slf4j does not have a logger backend.
    It returns the result itself, so you can chain it with other methods.

    It returns the result itself, so you can chain it with other methods.

    static <V> Result<V>
    ofTry(Class<V> type, ResultItemSupplier<V> supplier)
    A factory method for creating a Result from a ResultItemSupplier lambda which may throw a checked or unchecked Exception, but won't break the control flow of your application.
    If the supplier throws an exception, the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.
    Note that this does not catch Error subtypes, like OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError because they represent severe platform errors, which are considered unrecoverable problems that applications should not typically attempt to handle.
    Only application errors (Exceptions) are caught and wrapped safely as Result.

    If the run attempt throws an exception, the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.

      Throws:

    • ofTry

      public static <V> Result<V> ofTry(Class<V> type, ResultItemSupplier<V> supplier)
      A factory method for creating a Result from a ResultItemSupplier lambda which may throw a checked or unchecked Exception, but won't break the control flow of your application.
      If the supplier throws an exception, the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.
      Note that this does not catch Error subtypes, like OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError because they represent severe platform errors, which are considered unrecoverable problems that applications should not typically attempt to handle.
      Only application errors (Exceptions) are caught and wrapped safely as Result.
      Type Parameters:
      V - The type of the value returned from the supplier.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the value returned from the supplier.
      supplier - The supplier to get the value from, which may throw a RuntimeException or checked Exception.
      Returns:
      A new result with the value obtained from the supplier and a list of problems describing related issues.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the type or supplier is null.

    • ofTry

      public static Result<Void> ofTry(ResultRunAttempt runAttempt)
      A factory method for creating a Result from a ResultRunAttempt lambda which may throw a checked or unchecked Exception, but won't break the control flow of your application.
      If the run attempt throws an exception, the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem. If the run attempt succeeds, the result will not contain any problems. But either way, the result will never contain a value.

      Note that this does not catch Error subtypes, like OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError because they represent severe platform errors, which are considered unrecoverable problems that applications should not typically attempt to handle.
      Only application errors (Exceptions) are caught and wrapped safely as Result.

      Parameters:
      runAttempt - The run attempt to execute safely. It may throw a RuntimeException or checked Exception, in which case the exception is caught without breaking your control flow.
      Returns:
      A new result with no value and a list of problems describing related issues.

    • type

      public Class<V> type()
      This returns the type of the item wrapped by this Maybe which can be accessed by calling the Maybe.orElseThrow() method.

    • is

      public boolean is(@Nullable V otherItem)
      This method checks if the provided item is equal to the item wrapped by this Maybe. This is functionally equivalent to calling Val.equals(otherItem, orElseNull()). Note that this differs from Objects.equals(Object, Object) in that it also treats the equality of arrays, like int[], String[], etc., in terms of their contents, not their references.
      So the following code will return true: 
      
    int[] arr1 = {1, 2, 3};
    int[] arr2 = {1, 2, 3};
    boolean equal = Maybe.of(arr1).is(arr2);
    System.out.println( equal ); // == true
      Specified by:
      is in interface Maybe<V>
      Parameters:
      otherItem - The other item of the same type as is wrapped by this.
      Returns:
      The truth value determining if the provided item is equal to the wrapped item.

    • is

      public boolean is(@NonNull Maybe<@Nullable V> other)
      This method check if the item by the provided wrapper is equal to the item wrapped by this Maybe instance.
      Specified by:
      is in interface Maybe<V>
      Parameters:
      other - The other wrapper of the same type as is wrapped by this.
      Returns:
      The truth value determining if the item of the supplied wrapper is equal to the wrapped item.

    • orElseThrow

      public @NonNull V orElseThrow() throws MissingItemException
      If an item is present, returns the item, otherwise throws a checked MissingItemException, requiring you to handle it explicitly in your code. If you want to access the item without handling an exception, use Maybe.orElseThrowUnchecked(), which throws the unchecked MissingItemRuntimeException, a subclass of RuntimeException.
      The preferred way to unpack the item of this Maybe is to use this method, as it makes your intention clear and forces you to handle the case where the item is missing.
      If you can resort to an alternative value when the item is missing, use Maybe.orElse(Object) or Maybe.orElseGet(Supplier) instead any of the throw methods.
      Specified by:
      orElseThrow in interface Maybe<V>
      Returns:
      the non-null item described by this Maybe
      Throws:
      MissingItemException - if no item is present

    • orElseThrowUnchecked

      public @NonNull V orElseThrowUnchecked()
      If an item is present, returns the item, otherwise throws an unchecked MissingItemRuntimeException. You may use this if you are fine with the control flow of your application being interacted with by an unchecked exception.
      It is recommended to use Maybe.orElseThrow() instead, which throws a checked MissingItemException that you must handle explicitly in your code.
      If you can resort to an alternative value when in case the item of this Maybe is missing, use Maybe.orElse(Object) or Maybe.orElseGet(Supplier) instead of the throw methods.
      Specified by:
      orElseThrowUnchecked in interface Maybe<V>
      Returns:
      the non-null item described by this Maybe

    • orElse

      public @NonNull V orElse(@NonNull V other)
      If an item is present, returns the item, otherwise returns other, but neve null.
      If the supplied alternative is null, then this method will throw a NullPointerException.
      Specified by:
      orElse in interface Maybe<V>
      Parameters:
      other - the item to be returned, if no item is present. May never be null.
      Returns:
      the item, if present, otherwise other

    • orElseHandle

      public @NonNull V orElseHandle(@NonNull Function<Tuple<Problem>,V> handler)
      Returns the contained non-null value if present, otherwise applies the provided handler function to the Tuple of Problems associated with this result. The handler function can be used to provide a fallback value or perform some action based on the problems.

      This method is useful for scenarios where you want to handle the absence of a value with a custom logic that depends on the specific problems encountered.

      Example: 

      
 result.orElseHandle(problems -> {
     if ( problems.size() == 0 ) {
         return "Default Value";
     } else {
         for (var problem : problems) {
            // log or other processing
         }
     }
     return "?"; // or some other value
 });
      Parameters:
      handler - Function that takes a tuple of problems and returns a value
      Returns:
      Present non-null value or the result of applying the handler function
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if handler is null

    • orElseThrowProblems

      public <E extends Exception> V orElseThrowProblems(Function<Tuple<Problem>,E> exceptionSupplier) throws E
      Returns the contained non-null value if present, otherwise throws an exception created by the provided supplier function. The exception supplier receives the Tuple of Problems associated with this result, allowing rich exception construction based on available error context.

      This method is designed for scenarios where the absence of a value should interrupt normal control flow with a specific (potentially checked) exception.

      Example:
      result.orElseThrowProblems(problems -> new CustomException("Failed: " + problems));

      Type Parameters:
      E - Type of exception to be thrown
      Parameters:
      exceptionSupplier - Function that creates an exception from the problem tuple
      Returns:
      Present non-null value
      Throws:
      E - when no value is present
      NullPointerException - if exceptionSupplier is null

    • orElseThrowProblemsUnchecked

      public V orElseThrowProblemsUnchecked(Function<Tuple<Problem>,RuntimeException> exceptionSupplier)
      Returns the contained non-null value if present, otherwise throws a runtime exception created by the provided supplier function. The exception supplier receives the Tuple of Problems associated with this result, enabling detailed exception messages with contextual error information.

      This method provides an unchecked alternative to orElseThrowProblems(java.util.function.Function<sprouts.Tuple<sprouts.Problem>, E>), suitable for contexts where checked exceptions are undesirable.

      Example:
      result.orElseThrowProblemsUnchecked(problems -> new IllegalStateException(problems.toString()));

      Parameters:
      exceptionSupplier - Function that creates a runtime exception from the problem tuple
      Returns:
      Present non-null value
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - when no value is present
      NullPointerException - if exceptionSupplier is null

    • problems

      public Tuple<Problem> problems()
      Exposes a list of Problems associated with this result item. A problem is a description of what went wrong in the process of obtaining the value wrapped by this result.

      Note that a result may be present but still have problems, in which case the problem list is not empty.

      Returns:
      The list of Problems associated with this result item.

    • hasProblems

      public boolean hasProblems()
      Checks if this result has Problems associated with it. A problem is a description of what went wrong in the process of obtaining the value wrapped by this result.

      Note that a result may be present but still have problems, in which case the problem list is not empty.

      Returns:
      true if this result is present, false otherwise.

    • handle

      public <E extends Exception> Result<V> handle(Class<E> exceptionType, Consumer<E> handler)
      Allows you to handle a specific type of exception that is present in the problems associated with this result. If the exception is found, the provided handler is invoked with the exception as an argument, and the problem is removed from the list of problems. If the handler throws an exception, it is caught and logged, but does not affect the result.

      If you want to handle all problems in this result, irrespective of what type of exception is associated with them, consider using handleAny(Consumer).

      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception to handle, which must extend Exception.
      Parameters:
      exceptionType - The type of exception to handle.
      handler - The handler to invoke with the exception.
      Returns:
      A new result with the problem removed if handled successfully, or unchanged if not.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either parameter is null.

    • handleAny

      public Result<V> handleAny(Consumer<Problem> handler)
      Allows you to handle every Problem in this result individually through a Consumer which receives one problem at a time. If the handler throws an exception, it is caught and logged, but does not affect the result.
      After handling all problems, a new result is returned that no longer contains any problems, since they are now considered handled by the handler.

      If you want to handle specific exceptions instead of all problems, consider using handle(Class, Consumer). Which allows you to match and handle the Problem.exception()s associated with this result.

      Parameters:
      handler - The handler to invoke with each problem.
      Returns:
      A new result with the problems removed if handled successfully, or unchanged if not.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the handler is null.

    • peekAtProblems

      public Result<V> peekAtProblems(Consumer<Tuple<Problem>> consumer)
      Allows you to peek at the list of problems associated with this result through a Consumer which receives the list of all problems. If an exception is thrown during the process of peeking at the problems, then the exception is caught, logged, and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.

      This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.

      Parameters:
      consumer - The consumer to receive the list of problems.
      Returns:
      This result.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the consumer is null.

    • peekAtEachProblem

      public Result<V> peekAtEachProblem(Consumer<Problem> consumer)
      Allows you to peek at each problem inside this result through a Consumer which receives one problem at a time. Any exceptions thrown during the process of peeking at the problems are caught logged and then returned as new problems inside a new result.

      This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.

      Parameters:
      consumer - The consumer to receive each problem.
      Returns:
      This result.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the consumer is null.

    • ifMissingLogAsError

      public Result<V> ifMissingLogAsError()
      If this Result wraps a non-null item of type V, then this method will do nothing. If, however, the item is missing, then an invocation will generate a rich context message and stack trace from all problems associated with this result and then log them as errors to the Logger.error(String, Throwable) method, or System.err, if Slf4j does not have a logger backend.
      It returns the result itself, so you can chain it with other methods. This is intended to be used in a fluent API style which typically looks like this: 
      
  return 
    Result.ofTry(String.class,this::parse)
          .ifMissingLogAsError()
          .orElseGet(()->this.defaultValue);
      The logged information will contain the title and description of an existing Problem as well as the local stack trace either based on an exception in a problem or a newly created Throwable to ensure that the issue can be traced back to the source of the problem.

      Note: Please use logProblemsAsError() instead of this method, because it will log all problems, even if the result is not missing.

      Returns:
      This result, unchanged.

    • logProblemsAsError

      public Result<V> logProblemsAsError()
      Irrespective of this Result wrapping a non-null item of type V or not, if the Result has at least one Problem, then an invocation to this method will generate a rich context message and stack trace from its problems and then log them as errors to the Logger.error(String, Throwable) method, or System.err, if Slf4j does not have a logger backend.
      It returns the result itself, so you can chain it with other methods. This is intended to be used in a fluent API style which typically looks like this: 
      
  return
    Result.ofTry(String.class,this::parse)
          .logProblemsAsError()
          .orElseGet(()->this.defaultValue);
      The logged information will contain the title and description of an existing Problem as well as the local stack trace either based on an exception in a problem or a newly created Throwable to ensure that the issue can be traced back to the source of the problem.
      Returns:
      This result, unchanged.

    • ifMissingLogTo

      public Result<V> ifMissingLogTo(BiConsumer<String,Throwable> logger)
      If this Result wraps a non-null item of type V, then this method will do nothing. If, however, the item is missing, then an invocation will generate a rich context message and stack trace from all problems associated with this result and then expose this logging information to the Supplied BiConsumer which is expected to log the information the way it sees fit. This method returns this result itself, so you can chain it with other methods. It is intended to be used in a fluent API style which typically looks like this: 
      
  return
    Result.ofTry(String.class,this::parse)
          .ifMissingLogTo(logger::error)
          .orElseGet(()->this.defaultValue);

      Note: Please use logProblemsTo(BiConsumer) instead of this method, because it will log all problems, even if the result is not missing.

      Parameters:
      logger - The logger to log the problems to, it is a BiConsumer which takes as first argument the String message to log and as second argument the Throwable associated with the problem.
      Returns:
      This result, unchanged.

    • logProblemsTo

      public Result<V> logProblemsTo(BiConsumer<String,Throwable> logger)
      If this Result wraps a non-null item of type V, then this method will do nothing.       Parameters:
      logger - The logger to log the problems to, it is a BiConsumer which takes as first argument the String message to log and as second argument the Throwable associated with the problem.
      Returns:
      This result, unchanged.

    • mapTo

      public <U> Result<U> mapTo(Class<U> type, Function<V,U> mapper)
      Safely maps the value of this result to a new value of a different type even if an exception is thrown during the mapping process, in which case the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.
      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Maybe<V>
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function.
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item, if present.
      Returns:
      A new result with the mapped value and a list of problems describing related issues.

    • map

      public Result<V> map(Function<V,V> mapper)
      Safely maps the value of this result to a new value of the same type even if an exception is thrown during the mapping process, in which case the exception is caught and a new result is returned with the exception as a problem.
      Specified by:
      map in interface Maybe<V>
      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item, if present.
      Returns:
      A new result with the mapped value and a list of problems describing related issues.
